title: The AMI Meeting Corpus: A Pre-Announcement

author: Jean Carletta, Human Communication Research Centre, University of Edinburgh

segmentation: Given by Gene Carletta and is Co authored by a whole host of people from the AMI project and it's a pre announcement of the AMI Corpus.

Biology that's intended to support human interaction in meetings, and we tend to think of this at the moment is meeting browsers were also interested in on line meeting assistance for multimodal meeting recorders.
Recording is in a lot of the.
Kinds of issues that were interested in John summed up very nicely in the first talk.

I think there's there's quite a bit of overlap in in the kinds of issues, if not the approaches with the cable project, and one of the key things about the only project is that it's very multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary in the way that the disciplines interact with each other, and the project involves requirements.

And valuation specialists for the technology organizational psychologists who can tell us how groups work in in work environments in the wider workplace have groups within an organization serve the goals of that organization and about workgroup effectiveness and team working and how people make decisions and and the like.
And then linguists who study groups who know about how people take turns in in groups and how they pass the floor to each other.
And about things like how questions get answered in groups and and what backchannels mean in groups, that sort of thing.
Then the signal processing people who can deal with these these multimodal signals as they come in and produce something out of that.

You know that gradually builds up high semantic concepts to the kinds of things that people might actually want out of a meeting browser and computational linguists to do sort of a high of that scale and.
Know about things like question answering and dialogue modeling so you know.
I mean all these different kinds of specialists come together to address this problem of meeting browsing.

Did the motivation.
For collecting I'm only here to talk about the corpus and.

I perhaps with this credit goes without saying why you want to corpus at all, but it's important when you're when you're designing a collection to remember what the motivations are, and the idea is that this technological advancement has to be driven by the actual kind of data that you're going to run it on, and in particular for the corpus, we need the data to be plentiful, we need it to admit effectiveness measurement.
Now that means we need to be able to tell how effectively people did.

The task when they were trying to do in a meeting, and for instance, whether when they have access to a meeting browser they can do it more effectively than they could before they had the browser, and it you can't evaluate browsers well without that kind of effectiveness measurement, and effectiveness is an interesting issue for groups in its own right.
We need data that's been absolutely perfectly recorded on all modalities and captures everything about what the group is doing.
And we don't just need the signal data, we need the data to have been annotated for all kinds of things that get us from that signal to the higher level.
Things like like, question, answers and let what decisions were made.
And I key through all this is we need the data to be realistic.
So like what you would want to apply real meeting browsers too.
So these are.
All key parts of the data design that we have.
So those.
Those key design issues for the data actually want us to make slightly different decisions then I think.

Perhaps some of you will be used to because we've chosen for part of the data that we have not to record real meetings that are out there in the world and are happening anyway, but to specifically elicit.
Meetings in groups that don't have any history with each other.
You know they haven't been feuding for 20 years, you don't know what decisions they've made in previous meetings because they.
We know that they haven't made any decisions in previous meetings.
That's what is meant by Zero History Group in organizational psychology and.

Analyst Invitation allows us to to have that sort of group in it and also to limit the task to understand everything about the task that the group is trying to perform so that we can both limit the domain and the primary purpose of that is to just to be able to understand what's going on in the group, and it also makes it possible to build ontologies for the task that people are performing, which is quite difficult for things like.

So the next meeting corpus but you know you don't want to have ontologies built into all of your end technology, because then you can't port your technology to other domains, but the ontologies are very useful as your Azure understanding the one domain and working towards these domain independent implementations.

And another point about dialogue elicitation is that you can control the knowledge that the people have going into the task, and they all have roughly the same level of motivation because they're not performing the task for some larger organization where you know there might be expecting promotion and or, they might be disgruntled by what's happened to them in the past and and behave accordingly in the group.
And the other point about dialogue elicitation is you can build in outcome measures and be able to measure their work group effectiveness that I mentioned is important to browser evaluation.
So in the the Army hub corpus.
Which is the 100 hours or so or 4% meetings that we are doing.
The most stuff on in the army in the Army Project we have roughly 60% of it arising from a carefully designed designed elicitation task, which I'll describe in a minute.

And then the remaining 40% from other genres of elicitations and some real meetings and basically data that's designed to tell us where our methods designed on the elicitation task will generalize, and where they won't.
And to let us push out the boundaries of what we design in this more controlled setting.
So having defended why we have an elicitation to test it out.
I can tell you what the elicitation task is.
We bring together for people who have the task of designing a remote control in and around for meetings using a normal working office environment.
So they've got laptops with.
Software audit that includes email and web browsers and.
You know, text editors and all the things that people are ordinarily used to seeing when they work.
They've got things to do in meetings.
Things to do to prepare for meetings and.
The things that they do to prepare at the very beginning.
Give them some idea about different rules that there to play during the day.

So one of them will be project manager for the Group One of them is given enough experience, enough understanding of marketing to play the role of marketing expert, there will be an interface, user interface Designer and an industrial designer who understands about the materials and the components that go into making a remote control.
So we're going to crash course in.
What you have to know to to play these roles in making a remote control at the beginning of the day.
And that throughout the day they'll get different feedback from the organization.
So for instance, at one point the project manager will be told that the budget has been cut and they have to readjust their ideas for the design.
And at another point the marketing expert might be told what kinds of things are hot for the target demographics for the remote control.
So within this general setting, there are four meetings that are collected.
Their project kickoff, which the project manager tells them what the project is about and they just introduced themselves and get used to the meeting room.

Functional design of the remote control conceptual design and then bringing these two things together in a detailed design in the last meeting and throughout the day, as well as doing this task, they are given questionnaires that allow us to measure the effectiveness and how other team working together, whether anybody is under particular workload strain and things like that.
